description: This course is focused on programming the essential geometric and mathematical concepts underlying modern computer graphics. Using 2D and 3D implementations, it covers fundamental topics on scene graphs, computational geometry, graphics algorithms, and user interface design. Programming languages introduced include C++, OpenGL, FLTK and Python.
name: INTRO TO COMP GRAPH TECH

values.comments: This course is focused on programming the essential geometric and mathematical concepts underlying modern computer graphics. Using 2D and 3D implementations, the course covers fundamental topics on scene graphs, computational geometry, graphics algorithms, and user interface design. Programming languages introduced include C++, OpenGL, FLTK, and Python.  Overall, students learned a lot from this course. They thought that the course content was “pretty good.” Some found that as they progressed through the course material and completed assignments that built off previous ones, they felt a “sense of accomplishment.”   Students generally thought that Professor Badler was a “great lecturer.” However, some mentioned that Professor Badler was not always clear when answering complicated questions about the homework assignments.   This class, though fulfilling, was regarded by students as very difficult. The homework assignments required a lot of work, sometimes “20-40 hours every week.” In addition, exam questions were very meticulous and often took more time to finish than was allowed. This course was not recommended for anyone who has an “otherwise busy schedule.” CIS 120 is a prerequisite for this class.

This course is focused on programming the essential geometric and mathematical concepts underlying modern computer graphics. Using 2D and 3D implementations, the course covers fundamental topics on scene graphs, computational geometry, graphics algorithms, and user interface design. Programming languages introduced include C++, OpenGL, FLTK, and Python.  Overall, students reported learning a lot from this course. They thought that the course content was “pretty good.” Some found that as they progressed through the course material and completed assignments that built off previous ones, they felt a “sense of accomplishment.”   Students who took this class were generally pleased with Professor Boatwright, as he did an “awesome job teaching C++.” However, students did express that Professor Boatwright did not always respond to emails that would normally “warrant a response.”  This class, though fulfilling, was very difficult. The homework assignments required a lot of work, sometimes “20-40 hours every week.” In addition, students reported that exam questions were very meticulous and often took more time to finish than was allowed. This course was not recommended for anyone who has an “otherwise busy schedule.” CIS 120 is a prerequisite for this class.
